oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Proteomic variation and diversity in clinical Streptococcus pneumoniae isolates from invasive and non-invasive sites
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Bittaye, Mustapha
Cash, Phil
Forbes, Ken
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Streptococcus pneumoniae
invasive species
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Streptococcus pneumoniae is responsible for a variety of invasive and non-invasive human infections. There are over 90 serotypes of S. pneumoniae differing in their ability to adapt to the different niches within the host. Two-dimensional gel electrophoresis was used to discriminate clinical S. pneumoniae isolates recovered from either blood cultures (invasive site isolates) or other sites, including sputum, tracheal aspirate, ear, eye and skin swabs (non-invasive site isolates). Global protein expression profiles for five invasive site and six non-invasive site isolates representing five different serotypes (serotypes 4, 6, 9, 14 and 23) were obtained for each isolate and combined into a single data set using Progenesis SameSpotsâ„¢ software.
